"COMO CULTIVAR Phalaenopsis

 

O nome Phalaenopsis deriva do grego phalaina (borboleta noturna) e opsis (semelhan√ßa), e foi descrito h√° dois s√©culos por C. Blume, na Indon√©sia. √â uma planta muito decorativa, de flores dur√°veis, de f√°cil cultivo. Os Phalaenopsis s√£o encontrados na √Åsia, Filipinas, Nova Guin√© e norte da Austr√°lia. Neste habitat o clima √© geralmente √∫mido, quente e com grande aera√ß√£o, estando as plantas crescendo nas √°rvores ou at√© em pedras. Existem aproximadamente 50 esp√©cies naturais e atualmente um n√∫mero enorme de h√≠bridos est√° dispon√≠vel no mercado. Os Phalaenopsis n√£o possuem bulbos e sua reserva de √°gua e nutrientes est√° nas folhas. Seu crescimento √© monopodial.

CLIMA ‚Äì Quente. O clima ideal √© o litoral e zonas baixas, onde as temperaturas n√£o descem abaixo de 17 graus Celsius.

UMIDADE ‚Äì Alta. O ideal √© que a umidade se mantenha em torno de 70% durante o dia.

LUMINOSIDADE ‚Äì M√©dia. Os Phalaenopsis necessitam de menos e nunca devem ser expostos diretamente ao sol. Toleram cultivo em apartamentos com boa luminosidade.

CIRCULA√á√ÉO DE AR ‚Äì Sempre deve ser permitida uma boa circula√ß√£o de ar, o que ajuda a prevenir a forma√ß√£o de fungos e bact√©rias (regra geral para todas as orqu√≠deas).

REGA ‚Äì Os Phalaenopsis desidratam facilmente devido a n√£o possu√≠rem reserva (bulbos). As regas devem ser feitas imediatamente ap√≥s secagem do substrato, ou seja, a planta deve ficar seca durante o menor temo poss√≠vel. A cada 10 dias aproximadamente, as plantas devem ser molhadas com √°gua em abund√¢ncia (o substrato deve ser lavado) para elimina√ß√£o de toxinas e sais minerais.

ADUBO ‚Äì A aduba√ß√£o pode ser feita em intervalos de 15 dias e no caso de aduba√ß√£o ser semanal, a dosagem deve ser reduzida pela metade. A aduba√ß√£o deve ser feita preferencialmente no fim da tarde, para que a planta fique √∫mida por mais tempo durante a noite, quando ocorre a absor√ß√£o dos nutrientes. PLANTIO ‚Äì Os phalaenopsis por serem monopodiais crescem continuamente formando folhas alternadas a partir do rizoma. Geralmente o motivo do replantio se d√° por envelhecimento do substrato. Rizomas muito compridos podem ser cortados, desde que a parte remanescente possua ra√≠zes novas e saud√°veis. A parte cortada deve ser desinfetada com fungicida . As plantas podem ser plantadas em vasos de barro ou pl√°stico, que s√£o melhores para esta esp√©cie devido a reterem mais umidade. FLORES DEFEITUOSAS ‚Äì Algumas orqu√≠deas podem produzir flores anormais, com deforma√ß√µes na forma ou distor√ß√µes na cor. Os motivos podem ser v√°rios. Caso a planta produza flores deformadas em todas as flora√ß√µes, o problemas pode ser gen√©tico e neste caso n√£o h√° solu√ß√£o.

"Conclus√£o do primeiro link postado como resposta: ""These results permit us to conclude that K. brasiliensis
leaves have an antiinflammatory effect when picked
before plant blooming and a proinflammatory effect
when picked during plant blooming. Although the extract
had no lethal toxicity, more detailed studies of medicinal
plants are needed. The fact that the effects observed here
depended on the time of leaf collection may justify the
controversies often detected in the literature and in folk
medicine with respect to the effect of a given medicinal
plant. The results obtained thus far in studies currently
underway in our laboratory indicate the presence of
different compounds in the two extracts, which may be
responsible for their different effects."""
CONCLUSAO: de acordo com as opinioes desse grupo e de alguns amigos bot√¢nicos chegamos a uma conclusao. A especie em questao √© uma Mimosoideae, por tanto nao √© sibipiruna. "Conclusion
Based on the main findings detailed above, curcumin will lead to a promising treatment for Alzheimer's disease. The clinically studied chemical properties of curcumin and its various effects on AD shows the possibility to do further research and develop better drugs based on curcumin for treating AD. The recent review paper of John Ringman also supports some of the abovementioned properties of curcumin in AD;[50] however, large-scale human studies are required to identify the prophylactic and therapeutic effect of curcumin.

Several unanswered questions remain: What is the one main chemical property of curcumin that can be exploited in treating AD? What is the role of curcumin in other neurological disorders such as Parkinson's, Huntington's and other dementias? How does curcumin interact with neuronal plaques? Is it effective only as a food additive? Would it be effective when used alone or with other anti inflammatory drugs? https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2781139/#CIT50"
"Conclusions

The mode of action of the human gastrointestinal microbiota is not fully understood, but there is some evidence that it plays an important role in human health and that any disturbance may be responsible for emergent diseases. As some H. pylori strains are antibiotic-resistant, leading to therapeutic failure, finding alternative non-antibiotic approaches to treat H. pylori and other pathogenic bacteria is imperative. Probiotics diminish side effects and improve the efficacy of antibiotics, probably because they mimic the function of the human microbiota. Phytotherapy is a very promising therapeutic approach that has been used for centuries in traditional medicine. The herbal species used across the globe are highly diverse and only a few studies have identified the nature of the active ingredient or its mechanism of action. Safety must be assessed and each active substance must be characterized. Resistance against these new phyto-therapeutic agents should also be addressed. Bacteriophage therapy shows potential as an alternative to antibiotics, but it will take some time to verify whether it is feasible as it requires phage isolation and characterization. In summary, the mode of action underlying the described alternative therapies is largely unknown and future research in the field is greatly needed. https://academic.oup.com/femspd/article/63/2/153/542208/Alternative-therapies-for-Helicobacter-pylori"

"Copious choices
The following list was cobbled from the literature and my observations.

'Abbeville Blue' ‚Äì Produces deep blue flowers; selected in early 1990 by Louisiana Nursery.

'Alba' [f. alba (Weston) Rehder] ‚Äì White flowers.

'Arnold's Cutleaf' ‚Äì Leaflets like a dissected Japanese maple, blue-purple-lavender flowers, grows 10 feet by 10 feet.

Blue Diddley ‚Äì Lavender-blue flowers on a small, 3-6 feet by 3-6 feet shrub; Proven Winners 2015 introduction.

Blue Puffball ‚Äì Unique to the world of Vitex, this compact, 3 foot by 3 foot, densely branched shrub, produces copious blue flowers in summer. Foliage is a rich glistening blue-green with resistance to leaf spot. Flowers develop on new growth, so prune spent flowers to induce another flush of bloom. Quantum leap forward in Vitex breeding and will be available in 2016. Bred by Plant Introductions Inc. and introduced by Bailey Nurseries in the First Editions brand.

'Blue Spire' ‚Äì Mentioned without description in RHS Plant Finder 2013.

'Blushing Bride' ‚Äì Also mentioned without description in RHS Plant Finder.

'Blushing Spires' ‚Äì Soft pink flowers, growth more restrained; from Niche Gardens, N.C.

'Carolina Blue' ‚Äì LSU, no description.

Cooke's Blue ‚Äì Blue-lavender flowers, 15-25 feet by 15-25 feet from L.E. Cooke.

Cooke's Pink ‚Äì Pink flowers, 15-25 feet by 15-25 feet from L.E. Cooke.

Cooke's Purple ‚Äì Purple flowers, 15-25 feet by 15-25 feet from L.E. Cooke.

Cooke's White ‚Äì White flowers, 15-25 feet by 15-25 feet from L.E. Cooke.

Delta Blues ‚Äì Rich purple-blue flowers in compact panicles on a more refined plant, 8 to 10 feet high and wide, discovered by Matthew A. Dirr. Grew two-thirds the size of 'Shoal Creek' in one year. Introduced by Plant Introductions Inc., and available through Bailey's First Editions brand. This is a great garden plant, especially for the richness of the flower color and abundance of panicles on a smaller statured plant than the old oafy cultivars. Would make a pretty container standard tree for summer color.

'Fletcher Pink' ‚Äì A pale pink to lavender-pink flowered selection.

'Flora Ann' ‚Äì Pinker great-grandchild of 'Salinas Pink,' named for Flora Ann Bynum of Old Salem, N. C., introduced by Greg Grant of Arcadia, Texas. Grant continues to evaluate open-pollinated seedlings for richer, deeper pink colors.

'Le Compte' ‚Äì Discovered and described by Greg Grant as the ""most beautiful Vitex I ever saw."" Sapphire-blue flowers in long inflorescences. Found in ""a little old yard in Le Compte, La.""

'Lilac Queen' ‚Äì Lavender flowers, broad-spreading, multi-stemmed shrub, 20 feet by 18 feet, introduced by Plantation Tree Co., Selma, Ala.

'Mississippi Blues' ‚Äì More compact selection yet still will grow to 12 feet; robust grower with deeper blue flowers similar to 'Abbeville Blue;' there are essentially no differences in flower color among 'Mississippi Blues,' 'Abbeville Blue' and 'Shoal Creek' based on comparisons of the three cultivars in Georgia trials.

'Montrose Purple' ‚Äì Produces rich violet flowers in large inflorescences; strong-growing form, 8 to 10 feet by 8 to 10 feet, rated just after 'Shoal Creek' in Longwood trials; an introduction by Nancy Goodwin of Hillsborough, N.C.

'Patton's Pink' and 'Pink Sensation' ‚Äì LSU, no description.

'Rosea' ‚Äì Pink flowers.

'Salinas Pink' ‚Äì Light pink flowers; from a yard north of downtown San Antonio; Greg Grant introduction.

'Sapphire' ‚Äì Not sure of veracity of the name, might equate with 'Le Compte.'

'Sensation' ('Sensational') ‚Äì Mid-blue, offered by Gossler Farms Nursery, Springfield, Ore.

'Shoal Creek' ‚Äì Large, blue-violet flowers in 12- to 18-inch long inflorescences and leaf spot resistance, although have observed leaf spots on plants under overhead water.

'Silver Spire' ‚Äì Cleaner white flowers than 'Alba' and good vigor.

'Snow Spire' ‚Äì White flowers in panicles as large as the species.

'Woodlander's White' ‚Äì Another white-flowered selection."

"Cuscuta racemosa (Convolvulaceae), como disse o Manoel. 

S√£o holoparasitas , adentram os tecidos e ""roubam"" a seiva elaborada da planta - por isso n√£o s√£o verdes, n√£o precisam fotossintetizar. Elas podem cobrir a planta e se alastram com facilidade, s√£o agressivas.

Cuscuta racemosa, planta imprescind√≠vel para a alimenta√ß√£o da avifauna.
Cuscuta racemosa.  Parasita completo, n√£o faz fotoss√≠ntese. Mata a hospedeira.  S√≥ uma poda radical da hospedeira pode acabar com ele. Herbicidas n√£o funcionam nele porque n√£o faz a fotoss√≠ntese.
Cuscuta racemosa. Parasita total, n√£o faz nenhuma fotoss√≠ntese. Qualquer herbicida que for usado, s√≥ funciona se matar a hospedeira. Conforme o caso, uma poda radical pode salvar a planta. Mas depois da poda tem-se que examinar bem para n√£o deixar nada dela.

Cuscuta sp (Convolvulaceae) √© g√™nero parasita e como tudo na natureza tem o seu porque e sua fun√ß√£o. S√£o seletivas e n√£o parasitam qualquer planta. Nas cidades Hibiscus rosa-sinensis e Euphorbia millii s√£o muito requisitadas como hospedeiros. Elas tem seu ciclo de vida e reprodu√ß√£o como qualquer outro vegetal. "Da tese do Leandro sobre a familia: ""Cerca de 1% das esp√©cies de Angiospermas √© parasita (Westwood et al. 2010) e do ponto de vista molecular, sabe-se que plantas parasitas originaram-se em ao menos 11 linhagens evolutivas independentes (Barkman et al. 2007). Essas esp√©cies s√£o conhecidas, principalmente, pelo efeito nocivo que sua invas√£o provoca em monoculturas e outras planta√ß√µes, trazendo grandes preju√≠zos econ√¥micos √† sociedade (Yoshida & Shirasu 2012). Na √∫ltima d√©cada, estudos t√™m revertido essa vis√£o e atra√≠do aten√ß√£o tamb√©m para sua import√¢ncia na compreens√£o de mecanismos evolutivos pouco conhecidos (Lemaire et al. 2011; Su & Hu 2012; Xi et al. 2012). Tem sido demonstrado que, na realidade, as plantas parasitas desempenham papel fundamental na din√¢mica de ecossistemas naturais (Bardgett et al. 2006; Watson 2009).
No holoparasitismo, modo mais extremo de intera√ß√£o paras√≠tica, os organismos extraem do hospedeiro todos os compostos org√¢nicos e inorg√¢nicos necess√°rios ao seu desenvolvimento (Kuijt 1969). Holoparasitas s√£o vegetais heterotr√≥ficos (Krause & Scharff 2014) que possuem not√°vel comprometimento evolutivo com seu estilo de vida (Li et al. 2013; Wicke et al. 2013). Isso pode ser demonstrado por converg√™ncias adaptativas compartilhadas pelos diferentes grupos que o representam, como a presen√ßa de √≥rg√£os vegetativos muito modificados (e.g. folhas reduzidas a escamas, haust√≥rios e t√∫beras), a aus√™ncia completa de clorofila, al√©m de um genoma plastidial muito reduzido e rico em dele√ß√µes (Wolfe et al. 1992; Nickrent et al. 1997). O holoparasitismo est√° presente em oito das 11 linhagens paras√≠ticas e somam nove fam√≠lias, 48 g√™neros e aproximadamente 390 esp√©cies (Heide-J√∏rgensen 2008).

Da Tese do pr√≥prio Leandro Cardoso. "Borchsenius & Olesen (1990) descrevem um mecanismo mutual√≠stico na poliniza√ß√£o de L. bolivianum no Equador. J√° o mecanismo reprodutivo envolve ao menos cinco esp√©cies de besouros (Insecta: Coleoptera) que interagem com as infloresc√™ncias da seguinte forma: algumas esp√©cies de Chrysomelidae, Curculionidae e Nitidulidae pousam no ch√£o pr√≥ximo as plantas ou diretamente sobre a parte estaminada.
